results.title: Pitcha this : memories of Fitzroy : Foundation for Young Australians : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: May Andy, Marlene Scerri, Kelvin Onus-King, Howard Edwards, Frances Gallagher, Deborah Deacon, Arika Waulu, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Seven Indigenous leaders in the community tell of growing up in Fitzroy. From disperate backgrounds, they have all become heavily involved with the activism and community spirit of Fitzroy in Melbourne, to grow into inspirational leaders for generations to come. Here they share their experiences and passions, as well as the families and communities they love.

results.title: Victimised, Assimalised, Correctionalised
results.creator_credit: Howard Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a child, Howard Edwards was shunted from orphanage to orphanage. Made a ward of the state in 1956, he was abused and beaten wherever he was sent. His incarceration didn’t end there and for much of his adult life Howard was a target for police and he was often locked up at the slightest provocation. A large part of Howard’s journey towards healing involved reconnecting with his family, his work in the community and on the board of the Aboriginal Health Care Service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Howard Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: As a child, Howard Edwards was shunted from orphanage to orphanage. Made a ward of the state in 1956, he was abused and beaten wherever he was sent. A large part of Howard’s journey towards healing involved reconnecting with his family, his work in the community and on the board of the Aboriginal Health Care Service.

group_siblings.title: Inheriting
group_siblings.creator_credit: Arika Waulu and ACMI

results.title: Inheriting
results.brief_description: Arika Waulu has inherited quite a lot in her young life. A young fighter for social justice, her inheritance is two-fold. She inherited her land from her ancestors and her sense of social justice from her parents. But rather than take these things for granted, Arika embraces them.

results.title: Growing up on Cummera
results.creator_credit: May Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: May is a Yorta Yorta woman who grew up on Cummera Gunja mission. She warmly reflects on her days there, swimming and listening the the elders tell their stories. Moved away from her community, she experienced racism and prejudice but from those experiences learnt to overcome the boundries that others set up for her. She has since committed to a lifetime of learning and teaching and linking children and family back to their communities.
results.creator_credit_for_label: May Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Growing up in Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: Marlene Scerri, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Marlene (Scerri) Young gives us a picture of what it was like to grow up in Fitzroy in the 1950s. She lovingly tells of the closeness to her extended family, the friends coming to stay over and the strong sense of community, especially the Christmas parades down Smith Street.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marlene Scerri, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Marlene (Scerri) Young gives us a picture of what it was like to grow up in Fitzroy in the 1950s. She lovingly tells of the closeness to her extended family, the friends coming to stay over and the strong sense of community, especially the Christmas parades down Smith Street.

results.title: Childhood memories of Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: Deborah Deacon, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a tribute to her mother, the Indigenous activist Eleanor Harding, Deborah Deacon tells of her life and various struggles. Wanting a better life for her family was the main motivation in Eleanor moving from her home in Queensland to Melbourne. She eventually found a community in Fitzroy who supported her when she needed it at the start. Eleanor never forgot this, and devoted her life to helping out the community in various ways throughout her life. Her mother, as well as the elders of her community, have instilled in Deborah a strong sense of both individual and community empowerment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Deborah Deacon, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Eleanor never forgot this, and devoted her life to helping out the community in various ways throughout her life. Her mother, as well as the elders of her community, have instilled in Deborah a strong sense of both individual and community empowerment.

results.title: Pitcha this : life stories from A.S.H.E (Shepparton) : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: Natasha Craig, Troy Lovett, Chris Mansfield, Daniel McCrimmon, Brian Beckhurst, Misty Briggs, Joel Atkinson, Tammy-Lee Atkinson, Helen Atkinson, VicHealth, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nine stories of the lives of students from Shepparton’s A.S.H.E (Academy of Sport, Health and Education), as created by the students as part of ACMI’s Digital Storytelling program. These students, also members of the Indigenous community, tell of their loves, ambitions and, mostly, of the family that support and sustain them.

results.title: To my dearest son Mileak
results.creator_credit: Natasha Craig, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Even though Natasha Craig was pregnant at age 15, she was determined to have her child and embrace her new life as a mother. With the support of her family, she has been able to do so and doesn’t regret her decision as she sets up her life for her and her son.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Natasha Craig, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Skittles
results.creator_credit: Daniel McCrimmon, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Daniel McCrimmon moved to Shepparton eight and a half years ago. He tells us of his time there, his friends, favorite places and his ambitions for the future.

results.title: My tribute to my mum
results.creator_credit: Misty Briggs, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Misty Briggs pays tribute to her mother, a strong woman who had lived a hard life and overcame it all to give her family a better life.
